ygData.subject: Re: size attribute of species
ygData.msgSnippet: Dave, Thanks very much for your help. I replaced my ctml_writer.py with the new version and my test case is working now. I was trying to reproduce the classic

Dave,

Thanks very much for your help. I replaced my ctml_writer.py with th=
e
new version and my test case is working now. I was trying to reproduce
th=
e classic chemkin surface reaction example case (Si3N4 deposition)
discusse=
d in the Surface Chemkin documentation. I'm fairly
inexperienced with surfa=
ce chemistry, so I was doing this as a
learning exercise. The results with =
Cantera match the Chemkin results
very well. If you're interested in anothe=
r chemkin comparision, I can
send you the files. Thanks again.

Thanks also=
 to Steven for the suggested work-around.

Best,

Paul

--- In cantera@yaho=
ogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
>
> Paul -
> 
> Well, I d=
on't know how it got left out, but the 'size' attribute was 
> missing from=
 the 'ctml_writer.py' module that ct2ctml uses.  So 
> although Cantera sup=
ports using the size parameter for surface species, 
> it would have to be =
added by hand to the CTML file, since it is not 
> understood in the CTI fi=
le.  This has now been fixed, so you can check 
> out from CVS the latest v=
ersion of ctml_writer.py 
> ('Cantera/python/ctml_writer.py' in the reposit=
ory) and simply replace 
> the version you have in your Cantera Python pack=
age with the new 
> version.  I haven't had need to use the 'size' paramete=
r, and I guess 
> no one else has either until now!
> 
> Steven - your sugg=
ested work-around might work, but also might give 
> undesired behavior. Th=
e 'ads(S)' species would contain twice the number 
> of atoms as S, but sin=
ce its 'size' is 1, the site density would be the 
> same as S.  This would=
 affect the way the conversion from coverage to 
> surface concentration is=
 done.
> 
> I have found that it is all too easy to write a surface reactio=
n that 
> does not conserve surface sites, and then strange things start to=
 
> happen.  As an added check to help Cantera flag reactions that don't 
>=
 conserve sites, I often define an 'element' corresponding to each site 
> =
type.  For example, a CTI file might look like this:
> 
> -----------------=
----------
> element(''surf_site')
> ...
> species(name =3D 'S', atoms =3D =
'surf_site:1', ...)
> 
> species(name =3D 'ads(S)', atoms =3D 'surf_site:2'=
, size =3D 2, ...)
> ---------------------------
> 
> By declaring that ads=
(S) contains 2 'atoms' of 'surf_site', Cantera 
> will be able to check any=
 reaction containing it for site conservation. 
>   The size parameter must=
 also be supplied to do concentration <-> 
> coverage conversion correctly.=

> 
> An 'element' declaration with no atomic weight is assigned a very sma=
ll 
> but non-zero atomic weight, to avoid problems with dividing by zero i=
n 
> mass/mole conversion. You can use this to define anything you want to =

> conserve in a reaction (sites, spin, ...), without measurably affecting =

> molecular weights.
> If species are defined that contain only these 'vir=
tual' elements, 
> corresponding to an empty site, then mass fractions for =
these will be 
> nearly zero, but it is better to describe surface species =
in molar, not 
> mass, terms anyway.
> 
> Dave
> 
> 
> 
> On Dec 16, 2005, =
at 12:27 PM, Steven C. DeCaluwe wrote:
> 
> > Hi Paul,
> >
> > It seems lik=
e you should be able to dictate the size of your surface
> > species in the=
 reaction equation.  Wouldn't the reaction equation
> >
> > " ads + 2 S =3D=
> ads(S) "
> >
> > give Cantera all the info it needs in terms of the 'size=
' attribute
> > (where 'ads' is the unbound species, 'S' an empty surface s=
ite, and
> > ads(S) the bound species)?
> >
> > Your definition for the spe=
cies 'ads(S)' would have to include all
> > the atoms in 'S' (times two), b=
ut unless there's something I'm not
> > thinking of, I think this would hav=
e the same effect as declaring
> > 'size =3D 2.'
> >
> > Hope this helps,
>=
 > Steven
> >
> >
> >
> > --- peyelvington <pyelvington@g...> wrote:
> >
> =
>> Dear Dave and Group,
> >>
> >> I'm trying to use the "size" attribute of=
 a species to specify the
> >> number of sites that a surface-bound species=
 occupies (n_k in eqn.
> >> 3.4
> >> of the "Defining Phases and Intefaces"=
). I get an error from
> >> ct2ctml
> >> when I try to include this keyword=
. The ct2ctml.log file reads...
> >>
> >> Traceback (most recent call last)=
:
> >>   ...
> >>   File "./Si3N4.cti", line 73, in ?
> >>     note =3D "J =
3/67"
> >> TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'size'
=
> >>
> >> This species is declared like this in my cti file...
> >>
> >> sp=
ecies(name =3D "SIF3NH2(S)",
> >>     atoms =3D " N:1  H:2  Si:1  F:3 ",
> =
>>     size =3D 2,
> >>     thermo =3D (
> >>        NASA( [  300.00,  1000=
.00], [ 8.419753800E-001,
> >> 8.371041600E-003,
> >>               -1.3077=
03000E-005,  9.759360300E-009,
> >> -2.727938000E-012,
> >>               -=
5.248628800E+002, -4.527267800E+000] ),
> >>        NASA( [ 1000.00,  1685.=
00], [ 2.475398900E+000,
> >> 8.811218700E-004,
> >>               -2.09394=
8100E-007,  4.275718700E-012,
> >> 1.600656400E-014,
> >>               -8.=
125562000E+002, -1.218874700E+001] )
> >>              ),
> >>     note =3D=
 "J 3/67"
> >>        )
> >>
> >> Any ideas on where I might be going wrong=
? Thanks very much.
> >>
> >> Best,
> >>
> >> Paul
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>
